div.p:
AS he Å¿ayd not amiÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿ome Å¿enÅ¿e; who Å¿ayd, homo homini Deus, man to man is a kynde of God, in reÅ¿pect of the many-benefytes which Å¿ome men (though few) do procure to others: Å¿o with no leÅ¿Å¿e truthe is it thought, that an other wrote on the contrarie part, homo homini lupus, one man is a wolfe to an other, in that he deuoureth, deÅ¿troyeth, and rageth often tymes moÅ¿t rauenouÅ¿ly againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e, that be of his owne kynde and condition. Of which Å¿ubiect and argument, if we will beleeue the large and lamentable diÅ¿courÅ¿es of fondrie credible authors, we Å¿hal fynde the accompt made, that all the diÅ¿aÅ¿ters, miÅ¿eries, and calamities, inÅ¿ewing to man from all other creatures of the world, either in heauen, earth, Å¿ea, or ayer, or from the foure elementes together with their diÅ¿temperatures or violence, doth not equal the number of hurtes receyued by man from man. Wherunto we if lay on the other Å¿yde, the oppoÅ¿ite rule of ChriÅ¿tian religion, founded vpon loue of one man towardes an other, and bynding each one to do as he would be donn vnto: we Å¿hal eaÅ¿ely
diÅ¿couer the roote and reaÅ¿on, why Å¿o many do periÅ¿h, and Å¿o few are Å¿aued, of thoÅ¿e that profeÅ¿Å¿e the ChriÅ¿tian name, for that Å¿o few do perform the obligation to that name annexed. For if hell were raked, and all faultes rared, for which the inhabitantes of that miÅ¿erable dongeon are damned to thoÅ¿e eternall tormentes, I nothing doubt, but that of thowÅ¿andes or millions, Å¿carÅ¿e few would be found. at leaÅ¿t-wiÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿tians, that receyued not their woful Å¿entence, for Å¿ome abuÅ¿e or wickednes practiÅ¿ed towardes their euen brethren and neighbours.

And this may be preface Å¿ufficient for the breef diÅ¿couerie and reproofe that here I am to make, of a no torious iniquitie, practiÅ¿ed of late in our countrie, (where now we are wolues eating one an other by malice of hereÅ¿ie, though England haue no wolues by nature of Å¿oyle) againÅ¿t certain innocent and eminent men in catholique profeÅ¿Å¿ion, named IeÅ¿uites, to whoÅ¿e impugnation and general aÅ¿Å¿ault by all kynde of meanes, and by all Å¿ortes of euil affected people, is Å¿eemeth that the diuel and his angels, and all his inÅ¿truments at once, haue made a compact to conÅ¿pire together, by drawing all that is odious in the world vpon them: but eÅ¿pecially the practiÅ¿es of princes deathes and murders, wherof in my conÅ¿cience and knowlege (that haue knowen them, and dealt alÅ¿o with them very intrinÅ¿ecally for a good part of theÅ¿e thirtie yeares, and haue noted their deÅ¿ignementes, actions, and deÅ¿yres not vndiligently) no one Å¿ort of people liuing are more free and further of from Å¿uch cogitations then they, who deteÅ¿t Å¿uch bloody meanes in all their Å¿peeches, doctryne, and proceedinges, leauing them to the aduerÅ¿ary Å¿pirit of ProteÅ¿tantes, Puritanes, and Å¿uch other lyke teachers, who both preach, and practiÅ¿e Å¿uch attempes, as appeareth by the actes and monumentes of Luther in Germany, Zuinglius in Swizer-land, Beza in France,
Knokes in Scotland, and others els where, who haue rayÅ¿ed the turmoiles and tragedies that all men know, and haue brought many a iuÅ¿t and peaceable prince to deÅ¿truction, deÅ¿olation, and affliction; which no man can truely auouch of the IeÅ¿uites, notwithÅ¿tanding their zeale and feruour in Godes cauÅ¿e be not vnknowen, which is the fountayne of all this hatred, complaynt, & conÅ¿piracie againÅ¿t them.

Cicero Å¿ayd in his Å¿econd Philippica againÅ¿t Antonie, that by his particular deÅ¿teny it came to paÅ¿Å¿e, that no man for many yeares had becomen an enemie to the Roman comonwealth, but that preÅ¿ently he had byd warre to him alÅ¿o, as a cheef defendour therof. But this may be much more truely Å¿ayd of the IeÅ¿uites, in reÅ¿pect of ChriÅ¿tes comonwealth in our dayes, againÅ¿t whoÅ¿e churche & kingdome there is none lightly that ryÅ¿eth or Å¿tirreth, ether by hereÅ¿ie, atheiÅ¿me, wicked lyfe, or factious humours, but that ioyntly he becometh an enemy to IeÅ¿uites, and it is a comon note, and their crowne, and Godes Å¿pecial prouidence towardes them for their good.

But let vs Å¿ee in the particular point of killing princes, what deÅ¿yre there is of bringing them in queÅ¿tion, aboue other men. There was a king of France not many yeares gone, moÅ¿t Å¿trangely Å¿layne by a religious man, but no IeÅ¿uit. Was his order infamed, perÅ¿ecuted, or afflicted for the Å¿ame? no, nor ought it to be, he being but a particular man, whoÅ¿e fault in no right could be layde vpon a multitude. Some yeares after, the king that now is, was aÅ¿Å¿aulted by a yong man, that had Å¿tudied in the IeÅ¿uites Å¿chooles only, but now did not, nor was he euer of them, nor appertayned any way to them; yet were all IeÅ¿uites driuen out of France, and purÅ¿ued for this fact as murderers of princes, notwithÅ¿tanding by publique Å¿enteÌce of the PariÅ¿ian magiÅ¿trate, they were cleered of all participatioÌ, councel, or knowlege
of the yong mans fault. What is the cauÅ¿e of this difference? that which Cicero before mentioned, his zeale and fidelitie to his common-wealth.

Of late there were publiÅ¿hed diuers pamphletes, of an intent that one Peter Panne a flemiÅ¿h cooper Å¿hould haue, to kill the Counte MoriÅ¿Å¿e, gouernour of thee rebelled Å¿tates of Holland and Zeland for which alÅ¿o the Å¿ayd Peter Panne was beheaded; and to the end there Å¿hould not want the ordinary Å¿olemnitie of hauing a IeÅ¿uit in one end of the tale, it was faygned and Å¿et downe in print, how that one father Oliuerius Manaraeus prouincial of the IeÅ¿uites in flanders (a very graue old man) with the prefect of the Å¿tudies, and Rector of Doway, Å¿hould be the deuiÅ¿ers and Å¿ticklers in this acte at Doway, vpon Å¿uch a day and tyme, with Å¿uch & Å¿uch circumÅ¿tances, which might make the matter probable to Å¿imple people, that cannot imagin the malice of heretiques. All which circumÅ¿tances, with the principal Å¿ubiect it Å¿elf, were proued afterwardes to be moÅ¿t falÅ¿e, by publique examination, and teÅ¿timonies of magiÅ¿trates, in diuers citties of flanders. And among other poyntes it was proued, that the forefayd father Oliuerius, was more then 60. or 70. myles of from Doway (to wit at BruÅ¿Å¿els) at the very tyme that he was Å¿ayd to deale with Peter Panne in Doway) & that Peter Panne had neuer to deale with him in his lyfe, nor had any doing with the IeÅ¿uites, and that he was an heretiqoe, and had neuer receyued penny of money of IeÅ¿uites, nor by their meanes, as was forged in his pretended confeÅ¿Å¿ions. And many other moÅ¿t euident falÅ¿hoodes are declared in diuers bookes written about this matter, and approued by the aÅ¿Å¿euerations of publique magiÅ¿trates, in diuers townes and prouinces, Å¿ince that tyme. So as the impudence of this heretical deuiÅ¿e is made notorious to all the world.

And yet now leaÅ¿t England Å¿hould be behinde France
and Holland, and other places, in deuyÅ¿ing Å¿ome notable practiÅ¿e of IeÅ¿uites, wherby not only to auert meÌnes hartes from them, but euen to rayÅ¿e the hayre of mens heades againÅ¿t them; there hath byn brought in of late the tragical comedie of one Edward Squyer Å¿oldiar, Å¿ent from Spayne (as is pretended) by one William Walpole a IeÅ¿uit, to poyÅ¿on the Queen and Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex, with poyÅ¿on in a dooble blader, deliuered him by the Å¿ayd William, and diuers imbraÅ¿inges at his departure, as alÅ¿o Å¿ondry exhortations Å¿ayd to be made out of holy Å¿criptures to the Å¿ayd poyÅ¿oner by William Walpole, for proÅ¿ecuting of his purpoÅ¿e. All which circumÅ¿tances we Å¿hall examin afterwardes, to diÅ¿couer therby the faÅ¿hood of this fiction. For albeit I meane not in this place to take vpon me to auerre, that all the whole narration touching Squyer is faygned, or that Squyer was innocent in all poyntes that he was accuÅ¿ed of, or hanged for (notwithÅ¿tanding his denyals at his death) yet dout I not, but to Å¿hew moÅ¿t euidently, that all and euery thing that concerneth the IeÅ¿uites, and William Walpole by name, condemned in this action, by a wrong name (for his true name is Richard) is a meer fable & malitious deuiÅ¿e of Squyer, or thoÅ¿e that Å¿et him a worke, to make Spayne odious, and to Å¿lander the IeÅ¿uites.

Well it may be that Squyer, after his returne from Spayne (whence he eÅ¿caped by flight and not by miÅ¿Å¿ion as Å¿halbe proued) hauing gone abrode with my L. of EÅ¿Å¿ex to Å¿ea, and that in his owne Å¿hippe, vnder pretence to diÅ¿couer great matters of Spayne, not fynding Å¿uch comeditie or preferment afterwardes as he looked for; might begin to caÅ¿t out Å¿ome wordes of diÅ¿contentmeÌt, and Å¿ay for his better credit (not fore Å¿eeing the danger that might inÅ¿ew therof) that in Spayne he might haue byn imployed by principal men, in great matters; and in this Å¿peech it may be alÅ¿o, that
father Walpole being a IeÅ¿uit, and the man that was beÅ¿t knowen vnto him, and had done moÅ¿t for him; for relief of his miÅ¿eries, after father PerÅ¿ons departure from Seuil; he might I Å¿ay, perhaps make mention of his name though he knew it not aright, as hath byn Å¿ayd: and that therin being taken at the aduantage, and preÅ¿Å¿ed to go forward partly by fayre promiÅ¿Å¿es, & partly by torture (as at the barre he affirmed that he had byn fyue houres vpon the torture) he might happen Å¿tanding thus between feares of condemnation if he drew back, and hopes of pardon if he accuÅ¿ed others, to begin to frame the tale that in his confeÅ¿Å¿ion is Å¿et downe. And when he would haue denyed it agayne (as he did at his arraynment) it would not be taken or admitted. It may be alÅ¿o that Munday, and Stanley, or other Å¿ome Å¿uch compaignions (for I know or remember them not) coming after him out of Spayne into England, and deÅ¿irous to get creditt, might (as the faÅ¿hion of Å¿uch folke is) being poore and beggarly, begin vpon emulation to appeach, and call Squyer in queÅ¿tion, as was obiected in the arraynement that they did, and as it fell out diuers yeares paÅ¿t, between Doctor Parry and MayÅ¿ter Neuil, that called himÅ¿elf Lord Latimer. The Å¿torie of which two frendes and compaignions, for that it Å¿eemeth not much vnlyke to this, both in the matter it Å¿elf, and in Å¿ome particular circumÅ¿tances, I Å¿hall heare repeate with great breuitie.

William Parry, after he had Å¿erued the Å¿tate of England, Å¿ome Å¿ix or Å¿eauen yeares by Å¿pierie in Italie, and other places (as himÅ¿elf confeÅ¿Å¿ed) he waxed weary, and to repayre his credit againe on the catholique Å¿yde, he went to confeÅ¿Å¿ion in Lions to a ScottiÅ¿h IeÅ¿uit, named father Critton; and then hearing that the Lord Paget was comen out of England to Paris for his conÅ¿cience, and that Doctor Allen (afterward Cardinal) and father PerÅ¿ons were come alÅ¿o to Paris to Å¿ee him, he
came thither in the yeare 84. and vÅ¿ed all meanes poÅ¿Å¿ible, both by himÅ¿elf and his frendes in that place, to enter into credit with the Å¿ayd Doctor and father; and when he Å¿aw that in no caÅ¿e they would deale with him in matter of Å¿ecreÅ¿ie or moment (though otherwiÅ¿e they vÅ¿ed hun courteouÅ¿ly, and were glad of his conuerÅ¿ion to be a catholique) he was greatly offended therat, and one euening being led by a certayne frend and countriman of his, to the biÅ¿hop of Rimini, Nuntius at that tyme for Pope Gregorie the thirteenth in France, he deliuered him a letter written by himÅ¿elf in Italian to the Pope; wherin he Å¿hewed firÅ¿t and confeÅ¿Å¿ed, that he had done great hurtes to the catholique cauÅ¿e and churche, by his former Å¿eruices of the Å¿tate of England, and that now he was to go thither to make recompence for the Å¿ame, and to do great Å¿eruices in fauour of the Å¿ea ApoÅ¿tolique, deÅ¿iring his Holines approbation and benediction, without Å¿pecifying any particularitie what he meant to do, as by the Å¿aid letter of his, yet heer in Rome to be Å¿een, is manifeÅ¿t. And to this letter did Cardinal Como anÅ¿were, and his anÅ¿were was deliuered by Parry himÅ¿elf to the Queen, and the Å¿ame produced againÅ¿t him afterward at his araygnment: but to go forward. The Doctor hauing donn this act with the Nuntius, he got himÅ¿elf away Å¿ecretly from Paris towards England without taking his leaue, either of Doctor Allen, or father PerÅ¿ons, and paÅ¿Å¿ing by Roan towards Diep in Normandy, he tolde on maiÅ¿ter Wattes a PrieÅ¿t there, that his diÅ¿Å¿ignement was in England, to raiÅ¿e a faction againÅ¿t the IeÅ¿uites, from which maiÅ¿ter Wattes diÅ¿Å¿uaded him, but he paÅ¿Å¿ed on, and as Å¿oon as he came to Diep, before he would imbarque, he wrote a letter to the Lord Burleigh for a paÅ¿Å¿eporte and order, to Å¿peak with the Queen at his firÅ¿t ariual in England, for that he had great matters to vtter: and Å¿o the order came, and he by Å¿ecret wayes was brought to her MaieÅ¿tie,

And to confirme this the more, he Å¿hewed her alÅ¿o the anÅ¿were of Cardinal Como when it came, as I haue Å¿ayd: and well knowing that it was no treaÅ¿on when himÅ¿elf vttered the Å¿ame, he inlarged himÅ¿elf in many particulers, about the manner and order how it Å¿hould be donne, as her maieÅ¿tie can remember, hoping therby to get great credit, which yet afterward turned to his deÅ¿truction.

There was Å¿ent ouer vnto Roan at the Å¿ame time, or very Å¿oon after, the forÅ¿ayd maiÅ¿ter Neuil to exerciÅ¿e the Å¿ame office of Å¿piarie, which maiÅ¿ter Parry had donne before in Italy, and waxing alÅ¿o wearie of his occupation, for that rewardes came out of England but Å¿lowly, he made great meanes in like manner to Å¿peak with father PerÅ¿ons, who by chaunce lay for a time in that towne, but Å¿ecretly, and in the end obteining the Å¿ame, and propoÅ¿ing his miÅ¿erie and affliction of minde, he receiued the Å¿ame anÅ¿were and counÅ¿el that Doctor Parry had donn before: to wit, that the beÅ¿t way of remedie, was to leaue that trade of life, & to returne to a vertuous & peaceable Catholique courÅ¿e, & to haue patience if for a time he were not truÅ¿ted by Catholiques, being knowen to haue bin imployd againÅ¿t them, and that as his credit had bin crazed by woorkes, Å¿o muÅ¿t his reputation be reÅ¿tored by deeds alÅ¿o, and by time. Wherto maiÅ¿ter Neuil anÅ¿wered, that he could not liue without credit, and rather then he would liue Å¿o: or Å¿ee men crow ouer him, he would aduenture far, and Å¿o they parted: and maiÅ¿ter Neuil returned into England, and there meeting with Doctor Parry, who was now growen diÅ¿contented again for miÅ¿Å¿ing of diuers Å¿uites (but eÅ¿pecially the hedÅ¿hip of Saint Catherins, which he pretended as I haue bin informed) they two fel into new diÅ¿courÅ¿es about that, which in my opinion neither
of them euer ment indeed, I meane the murdering of her MaieÅ¿tie, but the one preuenting the other in accuÅ¿ation, it was the Doctors euil luck to be hanged, who yet tooke himÅ¿elf for the more conning man. And the lyke hath happened to this our Squyer, that Å¿tood not a litle vpon his owne wit in Spayne, and hoped perhaps to inioy the labours therof in England; but dealing doubly, and diÅ¿Å¿embling with God and man (as Parry did) was taken as it Å¿eemeth in the Å¿ame net of his owne deuyÅ¿es, as by the Å¿equel of this narration Å¿hal more appeare.

And I haue taken vpon me the rather to wryte this breef diÅ¿couerie of his falÅ¿e and treacherous dealing againÅ¿t IeÅ¿uites, for that I knew him, and conuerÅ¿ed with him in Spayne, and with his fellow maiÅ¿ter Rolles alÅ¿o, both before and after their apprehenÅ¿ion by the InquiÅ¿ition, and knew the Å¿petial obligation they had to theÅ¿e kynde of men, whome Squyer now hath Å¿landered Å¿o lewdly, as many others do, that receyue help & benefytes by them. And I haue heard afterward being in Rome, by Å¿undry letters from Spayne, of the manner of their departure from thence by Å¿tealth, which was Å¿uch, as doth euidently ouerthrow all this whole fiction of poyÅ¿on geuen by father Walpole. And albeit I dout not, but that when the Å¿torie of this tragical fable Å¿hal come to Seuil, they will Å¿end many authentical proofes from thence, of the malitious falÅ¿hood of Å¿o fond an inuention, yet could I not omit in this meane whyle to preuent their further diligence, with Å¿o much as I my Å¿elf knew, and am able to Å¿ay therof, as alÅ¿o two other reuerend preeÅ¿tes beÅ¿ydes that came with me to Rome from Spayne, and knew both the Å¿ayd men and matter, to wit, father William Med. and father Iohn Wor. who were with me in Seuil and haue dealt with the parties. We all three together can and do teÅ¿tifie and proteÅ¿t vpon our conÅ¿ciences, that in our iudgementes it is a
meer fiction, for Å¿o much as concerneth F. Walpole, and his Å¿etting Squyer a worke, to kill the Queen & Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex, or geuing him poyÅ¿on for that end, and other lyke pointes mentioned in Squyers moÅ¿t ridiculous arraynement. And this teÅ¿tification of ours, wilbe Å¿ufficient (I doubt not) to Å¿atisfie the iudgemeÌtes of all Å¿ober catholique men, as we beÅ¿eech them that it may; and as for others alÅ¿o, if they be vnpaÅ¿Å¿ionate, and will admit reaÅ¿on or truthe for their Å¿atisfaction, I referre them to the argumentes and demonÅ¿trations Å¿ett downe in this diÅ¿couerie. Wherin firÅ¿t of all I will lay forth the true hiÅ¿torie of Squyer and Rolles his compaignion, their being in Spayne, and then of their departure or flight from thence, and laÅ¿tly by the Å¿ame declare moÅ¿t euidently, the Å¿ottiÅ¿h forgerie of this faygned calumniation.

In the yeare 96. when Sir Francis Drake and Sir Iohn Hawkins made their vnfortunate voyage to the weÅ¿t Indies, there was Å¿ent from Seuil a noble yong Gentleman, named Don Petro Tellio (that had byn priÅ¿oner before with our Lord Admiral of England, & Å¿peaketh great good of him euerie where, for his honorable treatie) and he was Å¿ent with Å¿ix or Å¿eauen light litle gallions (called Sabras in Å¿paniÅ¿h) to wafte home certayne millions of gold, that were remayning in Porto ricco, in the great gallion of Don SanÃ§ho Pardo, retyred thither vpon tempeÅ¿t out of the Indian fleet, a litle before.

Rolles gentleman (as he Å¿ayd) and Edward Squyer a Å¿oldiar, who being brought priÅ¿oners to Seuil, found there by their good happe F.
